Margaret tries to find water at a depth of 50-70 meters. She looks for areas with good rock formations and electricity nearby to power the pump.

To find water, Margaret starts by using a pendulum on a map. She then walks over the area with the forked hazel stick, feeling a strange sensation when she's above the water. She uses the stick to pinpoint the exact spot to drill. Her husband also dowses the area, and they usually agree on the best spot. If they don't agree, they keep searching until they do.

Margaret's ability to find water is not unique. Many people have been fascinated by this skill, and scientists have studied it. Margaret calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment", and it's the best explanation for her success. Without this skill, the Wilkins wouldn't be able to run their business.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**

I deal with a lot of planes during peak hours, and quieter hours at night. I find the job stressful and it can take time to wind down after a shift.

**E. Shop Manager**

I start work at 8:00 am and get the shop ready. I help customers, order books, and manage staff breaks. I work with publishers to choose new titles for the store. I usually finish work at 5:45 pm, or 9:00 pm if I'm on a late shift.

**F. Financial Analyst**

I start work at 8:45 am and listen to the news. I assess financial risks for companies and provide reports to clients. I work with editors to plan my stories and meet deadlines. * Be willing to take risks and learn from your mistakes.
* Learn to delegate, motivate, and communicate effectively.
* Be visible and accessible to your team, but don't try to lead all the time.

**Film Reviews**

**Abyss**

This 1989 film by James Cameron is a thrilling Cold War movie about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a submarine. The characters are memorable, especially the brave and funny foreman Bud. The special effects and production design are impressive, but the dialogue and character development could be better. The story is a bit predictable, but the film is still enjoyable.

**The Thin Red Line**

This 1964 film, directed by Andrew Marton, is an adaptation of James Jones' novel about the battle for Guadalcanal. It's a more traditional war movie compared to Terrence Malick's version. The film focuses on a single soldier and his sergeant, and it's often more faithful to the book. While Malick's film is more complex and poetic, Marton's version has its own strengths, such as a powerful flashback sequence.

**On Guard**

This 1999 film is a swashbuckling adventure loosely based on a 19th-century novel. It's a fun and entertaining movie with a great villain and some impressive sword fights. The film doesn't take itself too seriously, and the actors have a good time playing their roles.

**Character**

This 1997 Dutch film is a period drama about a brutal bailiff and his son in 19th-century Rotterdam. The film is visually impressive, with detailed costumes and settings. However, the story is a bit slow and the characters could be more developed.

**The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**

This classic 1966 Western has been digitally remastered for video release. The sound quality is excellent, and the music is iconic. The story is a classic tale of good and evil, but the characters are all a bit morally ambiguous.

**The Longest Day**

This 1962 war epic, directed by four different directors, is a big-budget production with many famous stars. While it's an impressive feat, the film is a bit too long and slow-paced for some viewers. The video release is a bit disappointing, as it was meant to be seen on the big screen.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. They can make a photo more engaging than a scene without people. However, photographing people can be challenging. You need to consider not only the technical and artistic aspects but also the actions, gestures, and expressions of your subjects.

**GROUP SHOTS**

When taking a group photo, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can also have some people sitting or kneeling in front to make it easier to see everyone's faces.

**POSING FOR PICTURES**

People often stiffen up when they know they're being photographed. To relax them, suggest they find a comfortable position. You can also ask them to fold their arms or put their hands in their pockets.

**THE RIGHT APPROACH**

Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when you are. This can create tension and even hostility. Most people will agree to be photographed and are often flattered by it. However, they may become self-conscious, so you may need to direct them.

**EYE CONTACT**

A photo gains impact when the subject looks directly at the camera. Ask your subject to look into the lens, but not necessarily smile. You can remind them just before taking the photo.

**CANDID CONCENTRATION**

An alternative to direct eye contact is for the subject to focus on something within the picture area. This can be easier for them and make the viewer feel like they're observing the subject unnoticed.

**EXPRESSIONS AND GESTURES**

Expressions and gestures can tell us more about a person than anything else. Look for familiar expressions like smiles, winks, anger, or tears.

**SITUATION INTEREST**

The background or environment can add interest and information to a photo. Try to exclude irrelevant details and focus on the subject.

**INTERACTION**

Photos of people interacting with each other can be great. Look for eye contact, physical contact, or reactions to each other.

**PEOPLE AND PLACES**

When taking photos of people in a new place, use a standard or wide-angle lens and move back to include the background. Ask your subjects to come close to the camera and compose the picture so that they form a foreground interest without obscuring the background.

**TO POSE OR NOT TO POSE?**

Decide why you want to take the photo. If it's to remember someone, you may want a posed photo. But for family photos, candid shots of events as they happen are often more lively and memorable.

Here is a simplified version of the text for a B2 learner:

**Emotional Intelligence: The Key to Success**

The way we work is changing. We're no longer just judged on how smart we are or how well we do our job. Now, we're also judged on how well we get along with others and how well we handle ourselves. This is becoming more important when it comes to getting hired, getting promoted, or even just doing our job well.

In the past, we were taught that being good at school was the most important thing. But now, it's not enough. Employers want people who can work well with others, who are adaptable, persuasive, and can handle their emotions and the emotions of those around them. These are the "people skills" that make up what's called emotional intelligence.

Emotional intelligence is the ability to understand and manage our own emotions and the emotions of others. It's about being aware of how we feel and how others feel, and using that to make good decisions. It's not just about being nice, but about being able to handle difficult situations and make tough choices.

More and more companies are recognizing the importance of emotional intelligence in the workplace. They're realizing that it's not just about technical skills, but about how well we work with others. In fact, research shows that people can improve their emotional intelligence over time, and that it's an important part of growing and developing as a person.

Emotional intelligence is not a magic formula for success, but it's an important part of being successful in our personal and professional lives. By developing these skills, we can become better employees, better friends, and better people.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a B2 learner:

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is an ancient Chinese treatment that is over 2,000 years old. It is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbalism, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but its role in treating pain has received the most attention from Western doctors. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for pain relief.

**How it Works**

Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is a state where the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are in harmony. According to this theory, energy flows around the body along special lines called meridians. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes out of balance, which can lead to weakness or illness. During a consultation, an acupuncturist will try to find where the energy is imbalanced. This is done by feeling the pulse on the wrist, examining the tongue, and assessing the person's overall appearance. The acupuncturist will also ask about the person's medical history, current health, and lifestyle.

**The Treatment**

An acupuncturist uses fine needles inserted into the skin to stimulate the flow of energy. They may also apply warmth from smoldering herbs or pressure at specific points on the meridians. The person may feel a gentle, pleasant sensation when the needle is manipulated. There are over 300 points on the main meridians, with many more used less frequently.

**How it Works According to Science**

While Western doctors do not accept the principles of traditional Chinese medicine, they have found that acupuncture can be effective for pain relief. Scientists have suggested that stimulating specific nerves can block pain signals and stop them from reaching the brain. Others believe that stimulating acupuncture points releases natural pain-relieving substances.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with chronic pain turn to acupuncture as a last resort. Commonly treated conditions include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and post-operative pain. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain suffered by terminally ill people.

**Modern Use**

Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia during surgery is a more recent development. This has helped convince some doctors outside of China that there is more to acupuncture than just mind over matter. In China, acupuncture is now used during various operations, including tonsillectomies and caesareans, and even during open heart surgery.

**Effectiveness**

Clinical trials have shown that 50-80% of people find acupuncture effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally quote a similar success rate. They accept that it may not work for everyone and that people respond differently. Traditional acupuncturists say that it usually takes between six and seven visits for people to feel real relief, but some improvement should be felt after just two or three visits.

**A Different Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine view pain differently. Acupuncturists view their patients holistically, taking into account not just specific symptoms but also underlying weaknesses in the energy flow and external factors that may be causing the pain. This approach is different from the way Western doctors typically view pain.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others reject traditional Chinese theory and subscribe to scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by applying traditional Chinese medicine can deep changes be brought about that lead to a longer cure. It is important to choose an acupuncturist who refers you to a medical doctor if necessary.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

In the 1860s, a new type of chewing gum was invented using a milky substance called chicle, which comes from a tree in the Central American rainforest. This gum was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, and it became a big business.

However, the people who collect chicle, called chicleros, have a difficult and dangerous job. They have to trek through the rainforest, avoiding snakes and insects, to tap the trees and collect the sap. The conditions are harsh, with high humidity and limited food.

Today, most chewing gum is made synthetically, with added ingredients like pine resin and softeners. The manufacturers claim that chewing gum can help reduce tooth decay by increasing saliva production. Research is ongoing to develop new textures and flavors, with many new flavors using artificial ingredients.

Interestingly, the United States imports very little chicle from Central America these days, as most manufacturers have switched to synthetic ingredients. The world's gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products, with claims that gum can help with stress, energy, and oral health.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a B2 level learner:

Conquering the Seven Summits: My Journey to the Top of the World

I, Doug Scott, am a mountaineer who has climbed the highest peaks on each continent. I'll tell you about my experiences on each of these incredible journeys.

A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)

I climbed Mt. Everest with my partner, Dougal Haston. We were in a snow cave when Dougal started talking to our equipment officer, Dave Clark, about sleeping bags. I thought it was strange, as we were the only two people there. I realized that the high altitude was affecting me, and I started talking to my feet! We had to be careful not to get frostbite. On the summit ridge, I felt a sense of calm and confidence with Dougal by my side.

B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)

Mt. McKinley is considered the most challenging mountain in the world. Dougal and I took four days to reach the base camp. We decided to climb "alpine style," carrying our equipment and food with us. The air pressure at high altitude made us feel like we were at 7,000m, even though we were only at 6,100m. We finally reached the summit, exhausted.

C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)

I climbed Kilimanjaro with Paul Braithwaite. We got lost in the jungle and had to find a rock pool with water. We decided to take a different route to the summit, as the original one was too treacherous. We were relieved to find a trail of rubbish, which led us to the top.

D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)

I climbed Aconcagua with my wife, Sharu. We joined a group led by guide Phil Erscheler, who took us via the Polish Glacier. We had to wait out bad weather for three days before starting our ascent. The glacier was icy and windy, but we reached the summit.

E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)

I climbed Vinson Massif with a team of guides. We traveled to the South Pole and then to the mountain. The air was crisp and clean, and the silence was surreal. We reached the summit in just eight hours, despite strong winds and temperatures below -50°C.

F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)

I climbed Elbrus with a team. We had to pay a commission to our guide to bring us into the valley. We acclimatized for a few days before starting our ascent. The wind was strong, but we reached the summit.

G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)

I climbed Carstensz with a team. We hoped to establish a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. We were warned about bandits, but we continued anyway. We reached the summit and were given a standing ovation.

I'm proud to have completed the Seven Summits challenge.<|eot_id|>

The river became furious, and the stream near our cottage was deeper than we had ever seen it. For three days, we prayed that it would stay below its banks. Luckily, the dam held, and the water began to recede. In the past, the river had flooded nearby villages in a similar way. I've been a film critic for The Front Page newspaper for the last ten years. Before that, I did some reviewing for other newspapers, magazines, and radio. I met Tom Seaton, the arts editor, who had also worked in radio and TV. He hired me, but he wasn't a traditional journalist. He wanted a team of critics to cover different art forms, like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would discuss our choices over lunch, with guests to make it a social event. It was a dream come true to be part of a new newspaper. I was worried that the paper wouldn't succeed in a crowded market, but Tom believed in me.

The original plan didn't work out, and we ended up doing everything by phone. The public preferred to associate a reviewer with a specific area, so I focused on film. Without Tom's support, I wouldn't be doing what I do today. I'm grateful for the freedom to write longer pieces on one film each week. I wouldn't want to review every film that comes out; it would get boring. Instead, I can explore my ideas and make the most of my writing space. But what's my role in the public arena? People usually choose which films to see based on the stars, publicity, or director. It's rare for someone to change their mind about a film after reading a review. So, if a film review isn't a guide for what to watch, what is it? I don't feel responsible for being 'right' about a movie. I just need to present my argument. I'm not a judge, and I wouldn't want to be.

Collecting is a popular hobby that many people enjoy. I have always loved collecting and I'm not alone - one in three adults collects something. Collecting is a world of passion, excitement, and joy. But remember, if you don't fall in love with an object, don't collect it.

People have been collecting things for thousands of years. In the past, people collected pebbles, stones, and seashells because of their beauty. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for the same reason. I have been collecting things my whole life, from flowers to pottery and paintings. My first collection was of stones I found in my parents' garden.

I was fascinated by the objects at the local museum when I was a child. I was lucky to have a school in a remote part of England, surrounded by hills. My parents would take me to the museum when they visited, and I would spend hours looking at the objects on display.

Many people collect things for different reasons. Some people collect because it's the only part of their life where they have complete control. For me, collecting is just something I enjoy doing.

There are many famous collectors throughout history. One example is the Duc de Berry in France, who had a room full of strange and interesting objects. Another example is Catherine the Great of Russia, who collected over 4,000 paintings.

You don't have to be rich or powerful to start a collection. I have collected all sorts of things, from tulip bulbs to china cups. I've even collected American rag dolls - 350 of them! Unfortunately, my collection was destroyed in a fire.

What I find interesting is how collections change hands and how certain objects become valuable. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a famous poet can be very valuable. As certain objects become popular, their price goes up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now valuable if you still have the original boxes and contents.

I hope you enjoy collecting, but remember, it's not just about accumulating things - it's about loving and appreciating the objects you collect.<|eot_id|>

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building with a roof. The yard was covered in sawdust, and the smell of wood filled the air. One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored and decided to climb up to the roof. They sat down and looked out at the lake. Michael suddenly said, 'I dare you to jump down!' He jumped first, laughing and rolling around in the sawdust. The others followed, laughing and feeling relieved when they landed safely.

After a while, they all lay down in the sawdust, telling jokes and having fun. Later, one of Michael's friends suggested they go up to the roof again and jump down. This time, they were all a bit more hesitant, but they went ahead and jumped. Michael was the last one left on the roof, and his friends were calling out to him to join them. But Michael was scared and couldn't bring himself to jump.

He stayed on the roof for a long time, feeling embarrassed and ashamed. His friends eventually got tired of waiting and started to leave. Michael was left alone, staring at the ground. He finally closed his eyes, took a deep breath, and jumped down. He lay in the sawdust for a long time, feeling miserable.

As the sun began to set, Michael slowly got up and walked home. He was late for dinner and his stepmother was angry with him. She told him he was old enough to get home on time and that he should stay in for dinner. Michael was still feeling embarrassed and ashamed, and he didn't want to face his friends or his stepmother.

Chocolate has a long history that dates back to ancient times. It originated in South America, where the Aztecs and Mayans grew a special tree called the cacao tree. The tree produces a fruit with 20-40 seeds, which are used to make chocolate. The Aztecs used these seeds as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water'. This drink was flavoured with spices and was only for special occasions.

The Spanish conquistadors brought chocolate to Europe, where it became popular in the 17th century. At first, it was very expensive and only the rich could afford it. Later, in the 18th century, chocolate houses were set up in big cities, where people could go to drink chocolate.

In the 19th century, a Dutch inventor called CJ van Houten developed a way to make chocolate powder. This made it easier to make chocolate at home. Then, a British company called Fry and Sons created the first chocolate bar in 1847. They mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate and sugar to make a solid bar.

In the 20th century, a Swiss company added milk to the chocolate-making process, creating milk chocolate. Today, chocolate is a popular treat around the world, with people in the UK spending over £230 million on it every Easter. However, some cacao farmers are struggling due to a decline in cocoa bean prices. Many small-scale farmers were forced out of business in the 1980s. As you enjoy your next chocolate bar, remember the people who work hard to produce the chocolate.

This can happen when you travel to a different climate zone or country and have to wear clothes that are not suitable for the weather. Airlines rarely reveal how many bags they lose, but it's a common problem for frequent travelers. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it's impossible to guarantee that your luggage will arrive at the same time as you do. The problem lies in the baggage system. They also have minimum connecting times, which are longer than necessary, to allow for baggage transfers. However, delays and security checks can cause problems, and human error or accidents can also lead to lost luggage. Large airports, known as hubs, are particularly prone to issues because they handle a huge number of bags. Even efficient airports can have bad days. Certain airports, such as Miami, have a higher risk of lost luggage. To minimize the risk, try to book direct flights and check in early. If you have a connecting flight, try to fly with the same airline and allow extra time for your transfer. Make sure to label your luggage clearly with your home and holiday addresses, as well as the flight numbers. If your luggage is still lost, report it to the airline official in the baggage hall before leaving the airport.

The structure of their feathers actually scatters light and reflects blue, making them appear to change color depending on the angle of the light.

Kingfishers are shy birds, but they can be easy to spot from a hideout. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket, and he was thrilled when a kingfisher came to sit just a meter away. However, it took him four years to get a good picture. He spent so much time with the birds that he missed school and became an "academic failure." But his passion for kingfishers paid off, and he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine at the age of 16. He now works as a freelance wildlife film cameraman and hopes to make the ultimate kingfisher film. His goal is to create a film with no narration, just beautiful images that speak for themselves.

'HOW TO HELP A CHILD WITH SPECIAL MUSICAL ABILITY

Many parents struggle to know how to support their child's exceptional musical talent. Some may not even recognize their child's abilities until they start to show signs of frustration. Schools usually focus on academic subjects, but children with exceptional musical ability need special care. This is where specialist music schools come in.

There are five music schools in Britain that provide a supportive environment for children aged 7-18 to develop their musical skills. These schools offer a unique combination of individual lessons, orchestras, and theory classes. Students spend most of their day on music-related activities, with some time for essential subjects like English, maths, and languages.

The schools are small and independent, with a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they are surrounded by like-minded peers. However, this can be expensive, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year.

Some parents may worry about the cost or the idea of sending their child to boarding school at a young age. The schools themselves are cautious about admitting children as young as 7, as they want to ensure the child is ready for the intense environment. They aim to produce well-rounded individuals, not just musically gifted ones.

While specialist music schools can be beneficial, they are not without their drawbacks. Some parents may feel that the academic programme is too limited, and musically gifted children may struggle with the pressure to succeed. It's essential to consider the child's individual needs and personality before making a decision.

For those who are equally gifted academically, there are alternative options. They can attend a school with a strong music department or combine their normal school routine with music training at a junior music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons and orchestral experience. However, this option may not be suitable for families living far from major cities.'

Want to get published? Margaret Stubbs is here to help. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I've written a story/book, where can I send it?" First, you need to research the market and find out about publishers. You also need to improve your writing skills. To do this, you should read widely and often. Visit your local library and bookshops to see what kinds of writing are popular. This will help you understand what publishers are looking for.

As you start writing, you might not know exactly what you want to write. Let's say you want to write love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories and read recent issues. Then, learn what kind of stories they publish and who their readers are. These readers will expect certain things from the magazine, and the editor will only accept stories that meet those expectations.

Many new writers send me their work, saying, "I've been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. But it's unlikely that the work is ready for publication. Most new writers send their work out too soon. It's rare for someone to be published with just one story. When you do finally send your work out, keep writing while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, twenty even. Each one will be better than the last, and you'll become more confident. Don't give up – keep improving your work.

I also advise not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Every successful writer has faced many rejections before getting published. To advance your career, consider taking a creative writing course or joining a local writers' group. This will help you gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and write every day if possible.<|eot_id|>

On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia at Baltimore station. There were more people than I expected. The station usually felt airy and clean, but now it was crowded. Elderly couples and college students were sitting on the benches, and a well-dressed man was walking around talking to strangers. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to New York. He then asked an old lady the same question, but she said she was going to Wilmington, so he moved on.

I noticed him asking other people the same question, and I thought it was strange. He didn't ask me, probably because I didn't look reliable. He seemed stressed and was asking people to tell him if they were going to Philadelphia. A woman reading a book told him she was going to Philadelphia, and he asked her for a favour.

He explained that his daughter was going to fly out of Philadelphia that afternoon and had forgotten her passport. He had told her to stay at the station and he would get someone to bring her passport. I thought this was a suspicious story, especially since he didn't want to go himself. He said his wife was in a wheelchair, so he couldn't leave her alone. I looked at the two of them and noticed that the man was holding a padded envelope, which seemed strange. It was stapled shut, so you couldn't feel what was inside.

People love dolphins because they are intelligent, friendly, and seem to understand human emotions. We often see them in movies and TV shows, but the reality is different. The Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says that dolphins are in a desperate situation.

Dolphins are found in many parts of the world, including the North Sea. Unfortunately, their numbers are declining. The population of North Sea harbour porpoises has decreased by up to 89,000. You might expect these popular animals to be protected, but they are not. This is a serious problem.

There are many different types of dolphins. Some live far out in the open sea, while others are found near European coasts. The bottlenose dolphin, for example, used to be common in British rivers and coastal areas, but now it is rare. The ones that remain are often injured and stressed.

Dolphins are in danger because of overfishing, which is reducing the world's fish stocks. This is a problem for porpoises and dolphins because they need to find food quickly. If fish in one area are removed, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which can be invisible to them.

Dolphins can also be harmed by pollution and human disturbance. They live in groups and use sound to communicate, but noise pollution from ships and other sources can disturb them. This can have serious consequences that we do not yet fully understand.

"GETTING FIT Exercise is essential for our overall well-being. It helps us stay balanced in a world that's getting faster and more stressful every day. There are many reasons why exercise is good for us, and few reasons why we shouldn't do it. Exercise helps us build strong muscles, improves our posture, and prevents injuries. It also helps us improve specific areas of our body, such as our thighs, stomach, and arms. Additionally, exercise benefits our heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

But exercise is not just good for our physical health. It can also help us feel better mentally. It can ease depression and tiredness, regulate our sleep patterns, and even help us manage stress. Exercise can also help with certain medical conditions.

There are many types of exercise we can do, such as aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, and weightlifting. However, it's important to start slowly and carefully, and to consult a doctor if you're unsure what's right for you. Good posture is also important, as it can affect how we look and feel. By stretching our muscles, we can improve our flexibility and prevent injuries.

The best exercise routine involves a warm-up, stretching, a good workout, and a cool-down period. By following these steps, we can ensure that our exercise routine is effective and enjoyable."

Rachel has had some scary moments during her dives, but she loves the adventure of exploring the deepest part of the ocean. Tennis players have to travel a lot, and that's why we split up, I guess. That was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport. Ice Skating: A Fun and Challenging Activity

Ice skating has a long history that dates back thousands of years. Archaeologists have found old skates made from animal bones. In Scandinavia, skating was a popular activity among the upper classes. In the early 20th century, skating was considered stylish and elegant, but it wasn't until the 1924 Winter Olympics that a new, more athletic approach was introduced by 11-year-old Sonja Henie. Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism, requiring both skill and physical fitness.

To start, it's essential to maintain balance and control. The position of your body is crucial, with your legs slightly bent and knees bent to keep your body centered. Relaxation is also vital, as it helps you to move smoothly and efficiently. When pushing off with one foot, make a small movement with the other foot.

As you gain experience, you can increase the length of your movements. It's also important to learn how to fall safely. Even professional skaters fall, but by relaxing and using your hands to get up, you can minimize the impact.

Once you're comfortable moving on the ice, you can try different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. However, it's best to start with figure skating and then move on to freestyle. Many ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn the basics and improve your skills.

To become a good skater, it's essential to practice regularly and focus on relaxation, flexibility, and movement. You can also combine ice skating with other activities like swimming or jogging to improve your overall health and fitness.

Chris Greener is the tallest man in Britain, standing at 228 cm tall. This is not surprising, as the average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade. More and more people are born who are very tall. However, this does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. Instead, we are returning to what our ancestors were like thousands of years ago.

For most of human history, people got their food from a variety of sources. They ate herbs, fruits, berries, and occasionally hunted animals. This way of life is still followed by some tribes today. Then, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming. This had a big impact on our diet and health. We started eating more carbohydrates like wheat, rice, and maize, which led to health problems like tooth decay and diseases.

In the past, people who switched from hunting and gathering to farming became unhealthy and underdeveloped. They were also shorter and weaker. This is because they were not getting the nutrients they needed from their diet. It wasn't until recently that people started to realize the importance of a balanced diet and began to make changes.

As a result, the average height of people in some countries, like the US, Holland, and Japan, has increased. However, this trend is not without its problems. For example, beds and furniture are still the same size as they were 150 years ago, and clothes manufacturers are having to make new sizes to fit taller people. The question is, how tall will people continue to grow? Scientists think that there may be a limit to how tall we can get, and that we may even start to shrink again due to climate change.

My oldest son said, "You're nice and warm, Mum, and the shed isn't." I asked the kids to gently guide the snake towards the door, and it slowly moved away. Without looking back, it slid up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail disappeared, my three-year-old son sighed and said, "That was one big snake!"

He has seen tourists stamping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and definition of the artwork. Some visitors even take parts of the drawings as souvenirs.

Researchers are divided on how to preserve the drawings. Some think that the best solution is to close the site to the public and only allow guided tours. Others believe that it is possible to let people visit the site, but with guides and restrictions to prevent damage.

The director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, Henry de Lumley, thinks that closing the site is the only way to save the drawings. Another researcher, Annie Echassoux, believes that the only solution is to rope off the area and provide guides. She thinks that it is not acceptable to say that there is no money to protect the site, as it is a historic monument.

Climbing used to be limited to mountains and cliffs. Now, with new technology, climbers can challenge themselves indoors or outdoors. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, French climber Francois Lombard is hanging upside down by his fingers on a climbing wall. The National Indoor Arena, where the championships are taking place, is also famous for the TV show Gladiators. Both events use the same climbing wall.

In the past, climbers would practice on cliffs, but this was limited by the weather. In the winter, they would either brave the cold, go for a walk, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for top climbers to stay fit. They used brick edges or stone buildings to keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom. Many sports centers started building walls specifically for climbing, using bricks with special edges.

One teacher, Don Robinson, built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He created a block of concrete with natural rock inside, which could be used in a wall. Many walls were built in sports halls throughout the 1970s, but they had some problems. They could only be built straight up and down, unlike cliffs, which have overhangs and angled rock. Once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the same old routes.

Here is the simplified text for a B2 learner:

Do you want to become an actor? If you do, you'll probably hear people say that acting is a risky career. And they're right - there are many more actors than there are jobs available. When you decide to become an actor, some people who were your friends will tell you that you're crazy, while others might have different opinions. But it's a personal choice, and only you can take responsibility for your decision.

There's no easy way to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and there's no guarantee that you'll succeed even if you complete your training. It's a combination of luck and talent. However, there is always a demand for new faces and talent, and there's the possibility of excitement, glamour, and even big rewards.

I've been asked many times to define what makes someone talented. I think it's a combination of natural ability and imagination. The latter is the hardest quality to judge. It's also linked to a person's courage and confidence in what they're doing.

So, why do people want to act? It's often hard to explain why you want to do something. In the theatre, the most important thing is the moment when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what drives all actors to act, wherever they perform.

If you ask successful actors how they've done well, they might shrug and say they don't know. They might know some things about themselves and their technique, but they take nothing for granted. They know they're only as good as their current job, and their fame might not last.

Disappointment is the biggest enemy of an actor. You might be working one day and not the next. You might audition for a part, but it might not be yours. Actors try to protect themselves from the stress of competing and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. From the start, you're saying that you're available, willing, and talented enough for the job. It's up to you to care enough, because if you don't, nobody else will.<|eot_id|>

Here is a simplified version of the text, adapted for a B2 learner:

Chris Greener is the tallest man in Britain, standing at 228 cm. He's not alone - people in Europe are getting taller every decade. In fact, we're returning to the height of our ancestors from thousands of years ago. This is because, for most of human history, people ate a variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and meat. They were healthier and stronger because of it.

However, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming and growing crops like wheat, rice, and maize. This changed everything. People started eating more carbohydrates and less variety of foods. This led to health problems and shorter stature.

In one study, researchers found that when hunter-gatherers started eating corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn was supposed to be a good thing, but it actually had negative effects.

Despite this, farming spread because it allowed more people to live on the same amount of land. But many people still didn't get enough nutrients. It's only recently that diets have started to improve, especially in countries like Europe, the US, and Japan.

As a result, people are getting taller again. In the US, the average height is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. However, this trend might not continue forever. There might be a limit to how tall humans can get.

Some scientists think we could reach a height of 193 cm, but others say that as a species, we might actually be shrinking. During the last ice age, humans were taller and rounder because it helped them stay warm. Since the climate warmed up, we've become thinner and smaller, even when we're well-fed.

As the planet continues to warm up, we might shrink even more. This means that the growth of humans could be offset by global warming.

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break their own rules. While some celebrities might agree to be photographed by paparazzi, most people in the public eye are upset when their private moments are shared on the front page. However, very few of them complain to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was set up to deal with these kinds of issues.

Rarely are these pictures in the public interest. Do pictures of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a famous actress's hotel balcony photo protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens pictures before and had a right to do so, but she didn't take any action. The PCC should have investigated this incident, but it didn't.

The PCC should also look into another recent story about a pop star's personal life. The star, like the actress, hasn't made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the initiative on this and other cases of invasion of privacy?

At first, this might seem like a good idea, but it's not that simple. If the PCC takes on this role, it would have to decide when to investigate and how to approach the person involved. If the person doesn't want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? There are many problems with this approach.

Additionally, celebrities and royalty might expect the PCC to investigate any story about them, and they would be upset if it didn't. The PCC would also have to monitor all British newspapers, which is a huge task. There's also the embarrassment factor to consider. Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, they might not want the further embarrassment of an investigation. Most people just want to move on with their lives.

One comedian was also a victim of the press, and he didn't complain because he was afraid the newspaper would run the pictures again with a new story, saying he was angry about it. This fear is understandable. People think they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to see an easy solution to this serious problem.<|eot_id|>

D) Barbara is confident because she enjoys her work. She's built up her confidence over the years by learning from her mistakes and working hard. She believes that you should like yourself for who you are, not try to be someone else.

E) Kim used to be too scared to speak up in meetings, but she eventually found the confidence to express her opinions. She realized that everyone gets nervous when speaking in public, and that the key to confidence is telling yourself that nothing is impossible.

**Nene Valley Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is a 12-kilometer-long railway that runs through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, where you can visit the railway's headquarters. The railway also has a two-kilometer extension that takes you to the quiet village of Yarwell.

**Fares**

The fares are as follows:

* Adult: £10.00
* Child: £5.00
* Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00
* Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park is a lovely place to visit. It has golf courses, a large caravan site, and plenty of public parkland with lakes, picnic areas, and a nature reserve. You can also take a ride on a miniature railway.

**Wansford Station**

Wansford Station is home to a unique collection of historic trains from Europe. You can see trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. The station also has a buffet, bar, and souvenir shop, but these are only open when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children.

**Film Location**

The Nene Valley Railway is a popular location for film makers because it can be made to look like a railway in any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie Octopussy.

**Services for Schools**

The railway runs special services for schools from May to July. Teachers can book a special educational pack for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train for a special trip. There are special fares for groups of 60 or more pupils.

**Private Hire**

The railway is also available for private hire for special occasions or company visits. You can arrange a special programme with buffet, bar, entertainment, and more. Contact the General Manager at Wansford Station for more information.

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis, the highest mountain in Scotland. It's a challenging climb because of its cold weather and steep slopes. I, Keith Hewitt, went on my first winter climb to the top of Ben Nevis. It was February, and our group planned to climb the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge, which is 600 metres high. We would camp for three days at the 'Carries', which are like big bowls cut into the mountain. We took tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for our boots because the snow was very hard and slippery.

Even though some of my group were experienced climbers, we took all the necessary safety equipment, including lights, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, but we were still a bit nervous. Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The climb was steep, and my legs felt heavy. I had to rest more often because I was the weakest member of the group. The others would stop and wait for me, but then we would continue climbing. I promised myself to train better before future climbs.

After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, which is only 1.5 metres wide and drops off on both sides. We had to be very careful and focus on each step. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye 48 kilometres away. But we were unlucky and a mist came down. Going down the mountain can be just as difficult as going up. We had to read the map carefully to avoid taking a wrong turn, which could lead to steep slopes that are too dangerous to climb in winter. I was relieved when I was back in the tent and could finally say I enjoyed the experience. At least I made it to the top!<|eot_id|>

A letter to the Newport Evening News

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside, I had my cheque book, address book, and my purse with £50 in cash and some credit cards. I didn't realize what I had done until it was too late. I was worried because I'm 72 years old and far from home.

I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man stopped and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened, and he gave me some money to get home. When I told the bus driver, he said I should keep the money. I got home safely, and soon the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. Amazingly, everything was still inside, including the money and credit cards. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. They were very kind and honest.

Sincerely,
Mrs. B. James, Newport

Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

THE ICEHOTEL

For a long time, the Arctic was popular in the summer, when the sun doesn't set. But in the winter, the few people who lived there had the snow and ice all to themselves. In the late 1980s, people started to think that the cold and dark winter could be a good thing. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to show his art in a special igloo in a small town called Jukkasjarvi. The igloo, called Arctic Hall, was a big success and many people came to visit.

One night, a group of visitors had the idea to spend the night in the igloo. They loved it and that's how the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world.

Every year, a team of builders, architects, and artists from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They use natural materials like snow and ice to build the hotel. The hotel is built in parts, and each part is opened to visitors and guests as it's finished. The building process usually starts in December and finishes on January 7th.

The hotel is built outside, so it's affected by the weather. When it gets warmer in the spring, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it's very cold outside. Guests are provided with warm clothing like overalls, hats, and gloves. It's also a good idea to bring extra warm clothing, like sweaters and socks, and shoes with extra space for thick socks.

If you want to visit the ICEHOTEL, you can buy warm clothing and other equipment on their website. You can order it when you book your visit, and it will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is in a village called Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to get there.

I got the part and had to take three weeks off from university for filming. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on my missed essays. I didn't tell my university friends about my TV work, but they found out and thought it was cool. It was an incredible experience, and I feel lucky. After university, I plan to pursue acting as a career. Although I'm not from an acting family, my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles, but haven't received any offers yet. I'm not sure how I managed it all, as I also had a busy social life. After filming finished, I didn't know what to do. I've since appeared in two college plays. 'Explore the Beautiful Douro River with Jules Verne Voyages. The MV Lady Ivy May is a comfortable "hotel ship" that can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins with private bathrooms. The ship has air-conditioning and amenities like a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Day 1: We will depart from London Heathrow and take a flight to Oporto. After arrival, your guide will meet you and take you to the ship. You will spend the night on board.

Day 2: After a morning tour of Oporto, we will return to the ship and set off for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes about four hours.

Day 3: We will continue our journey up the river. In the evening, we will stop at Peso da Regua, where you can try some delicious local food and drink.

Day 4: After breakfast, we will take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego and visit its cathedral, churches, and a museum. The museum is a former palace with an impressive collection of art and artifacts. We will then return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrower here. Depending on the river's depth, we may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. If not, we will take a coach back to Tua and enjoy the scenic views.

Day 6: In the morning, we will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. We will return to the ship for lunch and then take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for us.

Day 7: We will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and setting off down the river to Oporto. You will spend the night on board.

Day 8: We will arrive in Oporto in the morning, giving you time for some independent sightseeing and shopping before your return flight to London Heathrow.'

THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD

In the late 1800s, people came to Alaska in search of gold. A town called Iditarod grew quickly and became the largest city in Alaska. However, in the winter, it was difficult to deliver supplies to the town because the rivers and ocean were frozen. So, a special route was built for dog teams to travel to the town. This route was called the Iditarod Trail.

It took about three weeks for the dog teams to travel across Alaska. They would stop at special places called roadhouses where the drivers could rest and feed their dogs. The trail was used for many years until airplanes became the main way to travel.

In 1925, a serious disease called diphtheria spread to Nome, a city on the other side of Alaska. The only medicine to cure the disease was in Anchorage, but it was too far away. The pilots were not sure if they could fly in the cold weather, so the decision was made to use dog teams to transport the medicine. It took 20 teams of dogs just six days to complete the journey.

The journey was led by Leonhard Seppala and his dog Togo, who was very good at finding their way in the snow. The last part of the journey was led by Gunnar Kaasen and his dog Saito. At one point, one of the dogs, Balto, refused to go any further and saved the team from falling into icy water. Balto became a hero and the journey was a success. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as the famous journey in 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.<|eot_id|>

Welcome to Antarctica Sightseeing Flights!

Before booking your flight, here's what you need to know:

We take passengers on a 12-hour flight from Sydney, Australia, to Antarctica and back. The flight is usually divided into four parts: three hours to get to Antarctica, four hours over the continent, and three hours back to Sydney. During the flight, our expert guides will talk about the environment and history of Antarctica.

You'll get two boarding passes, and at the halfway point, you'll switch seats to ensure everyone gets a chance to see the amazing views. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half the flight, while economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half the flight.

While over Antarctica, we encourage you to get up and move around to take in the sights. The pilot will fly the plane in figure-eight patterns to give everyone a great view.

What if the weather is bad? We have 17 different flight plans to ensure we get the best views. Our captain chooses the route with the clearest weather on the morning of the flight.

Will you see penguins and other wildlife? Unfortunately, most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, so we won't be able to see them in detail. We don't land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. If you want to see wildlife, you'll need to join a boat tour.

Can you take photos? Absolutely! All cameras are welcome, and we even have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold-weather clothes.

Here is the simplified text:

Driving in the winter can be challenging because it's hard to predict what might happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and ice can be hidden beneath the snow, making it difficult to control your car. A car coming towards you might also slide across the road unexpectedly.

To stay safe, follow these two important rules. First, drive smoothly and avoid sudden movements. Sudden turns, braking, or acceleration can make your car difficult to control. Imagine you have a cup of hot coffee next to you and try not to spill it. Drive slowly and gently.

Second, pay attention to the road ahead and be prepared for anything. When there's a lot of ice, you need to look further down the road. Test your brakes by gently slowing down to see how long it takes to stop. Remember, you might be going faster than you think. On wet roads, leave double your normal stopping distance, three times on snowy roads, and even more on icy roads. Stay in control of your car at all times and you'll avoid trouble.<|eot_id|>

Since 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films, which is more than any other film industry in the world. Most Indians enjoy watching movies more than any other free activity, and 10 million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films often tell romantic stories and feature singing and dancing. People all over the world enjoy Indian films, and last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries.

Indian actors make more films each year than Hollywood actors, but they don't get paid as much. This is why Bollywood films usually cost around $2 million to make, while Hollywood films are never made for less than $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but they usually only act for a few years. However, Amitabh Bachchan is an exception. He is considered one of India's greatest actors and has starred in over 140 films over a 40-year acting career.

Here is the simplified text:

THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE

In the past, London didn't have a police force like we know today. In 1700, only a few old men walked the streets at night to keep the city safe, but they weren't paid much. As London grew bigger, it became a dirty and poor city. Many people were afraid to go out because there were so many thieves stealing money. In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding started paying a group of people to stop thieves. They were like police officers and were called the "Bow Street Runners" because they worked near Bow Street.

Years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown too big and needed more police officers. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force was created with 3,000 officers. Most of them walked, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are well-paid, and those who ride horses get even more money.

'ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you'll reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes over and thousands of Canadian fishermen visit every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and decorate them with bright colors. Then they sit inside and catch fish swimming beneath the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for 25 years. 'You need to dress warmly,' he says. 'Wear light but warm clothes, like two pairs of socks, gloves, and a few thin sweaters under a snow suit. Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small hole. Then you attach a fishing line with some bread and put it through the hole into the water. When the fish eat the bread, pull the line up. The fish are usually between 10 and 20 centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but I prefer to have a snack like chocolate after catching a few. Today, I caught 25! It's a fun sport, and you can meet nice people here.'
